items.id: Elizabeth I appoints Christopher Barker as Queen's Printer
items.label: Elizabeth I appoints Christopher Barker as Queen's Printer

items.id: James instructs Bancroft to secure positions for the translators
items.label: James instructs Bancroft to secure positions for the translators
items.description:
King James I of England sent a letter to Archbishop Bancroft asking him to contact all English churchmen requesting that they seek positions for the translators.

"Right trusty and well beloved, we greet you well. Whereas we have appointed certain learned men, to the number of 4 and 50, for the translating of the Bible, and in this number, divers of them have either no ecclesiastical preferment at all, or else so very small, as the same is far unmeet for men of their deserts and yet we in ourself in any convenient time cannot well remedy it, therefor we do hereby require you, that presently you write in our name as well to the Archbishop of York, as to the rest of the bishops of the province of Cant.[erbury] signifying unto them, that we do well, and straitly charge everyone of them ... that (all excuses set apart) when we prebend or parsonage ... shall next upon any occasion happen to be void ... we may commend for the same some such of the learned men, as we shall think fit to be preferred unto it ... Given unto our signet at our palace of West.[minister] on 2 and 20 July , in the 2nd year of our reign of England, France, and of Ireland, and of Scotland xxxvii."
items.sources: Walleshinsky, David (1975). The People's Almanac. Doubleday & Company Inc., p. 235

items.label: The "Wicked Bible"
items.description: Robert Barker and Martin Lucas' 1631 reprint of the KJV included a serious compositor's mistake, incorrectly printing Exodus 20:14 as "Thou shalt commit adultery."

items.label: The "Vinegar Bible"
items.description: At the top of the page containing the twentieth chapter of the Book of Luke, with its parable of the vineyard, the typesetter of this Oxford Bible inadvertently set the page-head to read 'The parable of the vinegar.'

items.id: First edition KJV printed by Robert Barker
items.label: First edition KJV printed by Robert Barker
items.description: The original printing of the Authorized Version was published by Robert Barker, the King's Printer, in 1611 as a complete folio Bible. It was sold looseleaf for ten shillings, or bound for twelve.

items.id: Cambridge releases an updated KJV text
items.label: Cambridge releases an updated KJV text

items.id: Oxford releases an updated KJV text
items.label: Oxford releases an updated KJV text
items.description:
Edited by Benjamin Blayney, this edition sought to overcome the numerous variants introduced by printing errors since 1611 and has since become the text of all modern editions of the KJV. To understand the types of changes Blayney made, consider these passages from the 1611 and 1769 text below (examples from Wikipedia).

1 Cor. 13:1-3 (1611) 1 Though I speake with the tongues of men & of Angels, and haue not charity, I am become as sounding brasse or a tinkling cymbal. 2 And though I haue the gift of prophesie, and vnderstand all mysteries and all knowledge: and though I haue all faith, so that I could remooue mountaines, and haue no charitie, I am nothing. 3 And though I bestowe all my goods to feede the poore, and though I giue my body to bee burned, and haue not charitie, it profiteth me nothing.

1 Cor. 13:1-3 (1769) 1 Though I speak with the tongues of men and of angels, and have not charity, I am become as sounding brass, or a tinkling cymbal. 2 And though I have the gift of prophecy, and understand all mysteries, and all knowledge; and though I have all faith, so that I could remove mountains, and have not charity, I am nothing. 3 And though I bestow all my goods to feed the poor, and though I give my body to be burned, and have not charity, it profiteth me nothing.

items.id: New King James NT and Psalms
items.label: New King James NT and Psalms

items.id: KJV produced by the King's Printer
items.label: KJV produced by the King's Printer
items.description: "This short period sees no fewer than thirty printings of the KJB. Careless mistakes continue to be found and deliberate changes start to creep in."
items.sources: Wong, Simon. “Which King James Bible Are We Referring To?” Bible Translator 62, no. 1 (January 2011): 1-11.

items.id: KJV produced by the Cambridge and Oxford University Presses
items.label: KJV produced by the Cambridge and Oxford University Presses
items.sources: Wong, Simon. “Which King James Bible Are We Referring To?” Bible Translator 62, no. 1 (January 2011): 1-11.

items.id: Attempts to standardize the KJV text
items.label: Attempts to standardize the KJV text
items.sources: Wong, Simon. “Which King James Bible Are We Referring To?” Bible Translator 62, no. 1 (January 2011): 1-11.

items.id: F. H. A. Scrivener's The Cambridge Paragraph Bible of the Authorized English Version
items.label: F. H. A. Scrivener's The Cambridge Paragraph Bible of the Authorized English Version
items.sources: Wong, Simon. “Which King James Bible Are We Referring To?” Bible Translator 62, no. 1 (January 2011): 1-11.

items.id: 1833 Oxford reprint edition of the 1611 KJV lists 400 word differences between the 1611 and 1613 editions
items.label: 1833 Oxford reprint edition of the 1611 KJV lists 400 word differences between the 1611 and 1613 editions
items.sources: Wong, Simon. “Which King James Bible Are We Referring To?” Bible Translator 62, no. 1 (January 2011): 1-11.

items.label: The "Printer's Bible"
items.description: "One amusing mistake from the printer found in some copies of the 1612 edition is the substitution of "Printers" for "Princes" in Ps. 119:161: 'Princes [Printers] have persecuted me without a cause' (the 1611 edition has 'Princes')."
items.sources: Wong, Simon. “Which King James Bible Are We Referring To?” Bible Translator 62, no. 1 (January 2011): 1-11.

items.label: The "Unrighteous Bible"
items.description: This misprint rendered 1 Corinthians 6:9 as "the unrighteous shall inherit the kingdom of God" instead of "shall not inherit."
items.sources: Wong, Simon. “Which King James Bible Are We Referring To?” Bible Translator 62, no. 1 (January 2011): 1-11.

items.sources: Wong, Simon. “Which King James Bible Are We Referring To?” Bible Translator 62, no. 1 (January 2011): 1-11.

items.sources: Wong, Simon. “Which King James Bible Are We Referring To?” Bible Translator 62, no. 1 (January 2011): 1-11.

items.label: Second major Oxford KJV edition
items.sources: Wong, Simon. “Which King James Bible Are We Referring To?” Bible Translator 62, no. 1 (January 2011): 1-11.

items.id: Weymouth's New Testament in Modern Speech
items.label: Weymouth's New Testament in Modern Speech

items.id: J. B. Phillips's Version rev. ed.
items.label: J. B. Phillips's Version rev. ed.
The New International Version
items.description: Complete version (including the Old Testament) published

items.id: Revised New Testament, New American Bible
items.label: Revised New Testament, New American Bible

items.id: New International Version, Inclusive Language Edition
items.label: New International Version, Inclusive Language Edition
items.description: Sold exclusively in Britain, labeled “Inclusive” because it used gender-neutral language. A host of conservative evangelicals, led by The Council on Biblical Manhood and Womanhood (CBMW) and WORLD magazine attacked this trend in NIV translations.

items.label: New International Reader's Version
items.description: New International Reader’s Version, intended for children, sold in the United States. Introduced some gender-neutral language. It is unclear whether Zondervan ever sold the announced revision that would remove gender-neutral language.

items.label: Today's New International Version
items.description: Also uses gender-neutral language, condemned by some conservative evangelicals.

items.label: New International Version, 2011 update
items.description: The NIV 2011 is marketed as an update to the 1984 NIV. This version replaces the 1984 NIV and the TNIV and is labeled NIV to minimize confusion.

items.id: William Tyndale translates the Bible into English
items.label: William Tyndale translates the Bible into English
items.description: While a number of partial and complete English translations had been made previously, Tyndale's was the first English translation to draw directly from Hebrew and Greek texts, and the first to take advantage of the new medium of print, which allowed for its wide distribution.

items.id: Tyndale graduates from Oxford with BA
items.label: Tyndale graduates from Oxford with BA

items.id: Tyndale graduates from Oxford with MA
items.label: Tyndale graduates from Oxford with MA

items.id: Tyndale hides in Germany to translate the NT
items.label: Tyndale hides in Germany to translate the NT

items.id: Wycliffe Bible banned due to association with Lollards
items.label: Wycliffe Bible banned due to association with Lollards
The "Gunpowder Plot"
items.description: The Gunpowder Plot was a failed assassination attempt against King James by a group of provincial English Catholics led by Robert Catesby.

items.label: Lady Jane Grey
items.description: Jane Grey's disputed reign lasted only 9 days, ending on July 19, 1553.

items.id: Cardinal Wolsey burns "heretical" Reformation books at St. Paul's Cathedral
items.label: Cardinal Wolsey burns "heretical" Reformation books at St. Paul's Cathedral

items.id: Caedmon, a monk, puts Bible books into verse
items.label: Caedmon, a monk, puts Bible books into verse
items.description: Caedmon's manuscript paraphrases parts of Genesis, Exodus, and Daniel and represents an early example of Anglo-Saxon poetry.
items.sources: Comfort, Philip W. "The Christian History Timeline—How We Got Our Bible." in "How We Got Our Bible, Canon to King James," <i>Christian History Magazine<i> no. 43 (1994).

items.id: Richard Rolle and William Shoreham translate psalms into metrical verse
items.label: Richard Rolle and William Shoreham translate psalms into metrical verse
items.sources: Comfort, Philip W. "The Christian History Timeline—How We Got Our Bible." in "How We Got Our Bible, Canon to King James," <i>Christian History Magazine<i> no. 43 (1994).

items.label: Amplified Bible
items.sources: Fee and Stuart, How to Choose a Translation for All Its Worth

items.label: John Purvey revises Wycliffe Bible
items.sources: Comfort, Philip W. "The Christian History Timeline—How We Got Our Bible." in "How We Got Our Bible, Canon to King James," <i>Christian History Magazine<i> no. 43 (1994).

items.label: Bede translates the Gospels
items.sources: Comfort, Philip W. "The Christian History Timeline—How We Got Our Bible." in "How We Got Our Bible, Canon to King James," <i>Christian History Magazine<i> no. 43 (1994).

items.id: King Alfred the Great translates the Psalms and 10 Commandments
items.label: King Alfred the Great translates the Psalms and 10 Commandments
items.sources: Comfort, Philip W. "The Christian History Timeline—How We Got Our Bible." in "How We Got Our Bible, Canon to King James," <i>Christian History Magazine<i> no. 43 (1994).

items.label: The 7th-century Lindisfarne Gospels receive English translation
items.sources: Comfort, Philip W. "The Christian History Timeline—How We Got Our Bible." in "How We Got Our Bible, Canon to King James," <i>Christian History Magazine<i> no. 43 (1994).

items.label: Aelfric translates various Bible books
items.sources: Comfort, Philip W. "The Christian History Timeline—How We Got Our Bible." in "How We Got Our Bible, Canon to King James," <i>Christian History Magazine<i> no. 43 (1994).

items.label: Invention of eyeglasses aids copying
items.sources: Comfort, Philip W. "The Christian History Timeline—How We Got Our Bible." in "How We Got Our Bible, Canon to King James," <i>Christian History Magazine<i> no. 43 (1994).

items.label: Millenary Petition
items.description: The Millenary Petition was a list of requests given to James I by Puritans in 1603 when he was travelling to London in order to claim the English throne. This carefully worded document expressed Puritan distaste regarding the state of the Anglican Church, and took into consideration James' religious views as well as his liking for a debate, as written in Basilikon Doron.While many of the main Puritan goals were rebutted, the petition did culminate in the Hampton Court Conference, which eventually led James to commission a new English translation of the bible, now known as the King James Version.

items.id: Richard Bancroft's anti-Puritan canons receive royal approval
items.label: Richard Bancroft's anti-Puritan canons receive royal approval
items.description: "The tension between the prelates of the official church and the Puritans grew during James's reign. In 1604, Richard Bancroft, archbishop of Canterbury, had a series of canons approved in which it was affirmed that episcopal hierarchy was an institution of divine origin, and that without it there could be no true church. This implied a rejection of the many Protestant churches on the Continent that had no bishops, and therefore Puritans saw in it a step towards breaking away from Protestant ties in order to reintroduce Catholicism in England. Besides this, several other canons approved on the archbishop's insistence were clearly directed against Puritans."
items.sources: Gonzalez, Justo L. The Story of Christianity: The Reformation to the Present Day. Vol. 2. 1st ed. HarperOne, 1985., p152.

items.id: Erasmus releases his edition of the Greek New Testament text
items.label: Erasmus releases his edition of the Greek New Testament text

items.id: David Norton's New Cambridge Paragraph Bible with the Apocrypha
items.label: David Norton's New Cambridge Paragraph Bible with the Apocrypha
items.description: The standard editions of the 1611 King James Bible (or Authorised Version) currently available give, with little variation, the text as established by the Oxford edition of 1769. They give the reader, therefore, a seventeenth-century text in mid-eighteenth century clothes—clothes which are neither original nor modern. In this new edition of the King James Version the text has been collated with the translators' original work in order to give the reader as closely as possible the exact text on which the translators decided. It has also been given consistent modern spelling and presentation in order to make it easier to read and study than standard editions. The text is presented is paragraph form, with marginal notes. The type is 10/12.5 Swift. [Publisher description]

items.id: CRC Church proposes to produce a new translation
items.label: CRC Church proposes to produce a new translation
items.description: Christian Reformed Church (CRC; formerly known as the Dutch Reformed Church) synod proposes to support the production of a new Bible translation.
items.sources: Stek, 'The New International Version: How It Came to Be'

items.id: Joint Committee on bible Translation formed by NAE and CRC to produce new translation
items.label: Joint Committee on bible Translation formed by NAE and CRC to produce new translation
items.description: Joint Committee on Bible Translation forms from the NAE and the CRC committees with the agenda "to call a Bible Translation Conference for the purpose of exploring the need for a new English translation or revision of the Bible."
items.sources: Stek, 'The New International Version: How It Came to Be'

items.id: Committee on Bible Translation forms to carry on the work of the Joint Committee
items.label: Committee on Bible Translation forms to carry on the work of the Joint Committee
items.description: A general conference (organized by the Joint Committee) meets to examine the possibility of broad evangelical support of the translation project  and examines the merits of other translations such as the NASB and RSV. Adopted this consensus: "It is the sense of this assembly that the preparation of a contemporary English translation should be undertaken as a collegiate endeavor of evangelical scholars." A new committee (eventually called the Committee on Bible Translation [CBT]) established to carry on the work of translation and discontinue the Joint Committee.
items.sources: Stek, 'The New International Version: How It Came to Be'

items.label: CBT adopts doctrinal statement
items.description:
CBT adopts the following statement:
All those engaged by the Committee as translators or editors shall be required to affirm the following article of faith: 'The Bible alone, and the Bible in its entirety, is the Word of God written, and is therefore inerrant in the autographs'; or the statement on Scripture in the Westminster Confession, the Belgic Confession, the New Hampshire Confession, or the creedal basis of the National Association of Evangelicals; or some other comparable statement.
items.sources: Stek, 'The New International Version: How It Came to Be', 244

items.label: CBT begins translation work
items.description: Translation work begins in earnest under the direction of Edwin H. Palmer, executive secretary of the CBT
items.sources: Stek, 'The New International Version: How It Came to Be'

items.id: Early release of 'New International Version' NT
items.label: Early release of 'New International Version' NT
items.description: The name "New International Version" is chosen; the text of the New Testament is published

items.label: Major revision to NIV
items.description: A revised edition of both testaments published which incorporates suggestions and criticisms gathered since the publication of the previous editions

items.id: CRC refers question to Calvin Theological Seminary; NAE becomes involved
items.label: CRC refers question to Calvin Theological Seminary; NAE becomes involved
items.description: CRC refers the matter to the faculty of Calvin Theological Seminary; National Association of Evangelicals (NAE) establishes a Bible translation committee

items.id: NAE and CRC committees hold joint consultation
items.label: NAE and CRC committees hold joint consultation
items.description: NAE committee meets with CRC committee about the translation project and agrees to hold a special meeting reaching beyond the constituencies of both (this meeting was not officially sponsored by either the NAE or the CRC)

items.id: CRC committee notes growing project scope
items.label: CRC committee notes growing project scope
items.description: CRC committee decides that the project is too large to be completed without additional preparations

items.label: Colorado Springs Guidelines produced
items.description: International Bible Society (IBS) announces plans to revise the NIV to use the gender-neutral language already employed in the NIVI and the NIrV. Announcement evokes furor from evangelicals and fundamentalists alike. James Dobson convenes meeting of enraged evangelicals and Zondervan/NIV translators on May 27 in Colorado Springs where Zondervan agrees in the "Colorado Springs Guidelines" not to revise the NIV to use gender-neutral language.  As a result, the NIVI was pulled and the NIrV was scheduled for revision to bring its gender usage in line with the 1984 NIV
items.sources: Gene Edward Veith, "Beyond Stealth," World, January 29, 2005, 30; Susan Olasky, "Bailing Out of the Stealth Bible," World, June 14, 1997, 13-14.

items.label: Zondervan reprints NIrV
items.description: Zondervan reprints the gender-neutral NIrV contrary to 1997 promises.

items.label: TNIV announced by IBS
items.description: IBS announces plans to publish a “new translation” (the Today's New International Version or TNIV) to be sold alongside the existing NIV. Conservatives claim that the announcement is a ploy to enable Zondervan to publish a gender-neutral version while complying with the Colorado Springs Guidelines.

items.id: Tischendorf discovers Codex Sinaiticus at St. Catherine's Monastery
items.label: Tischendorf discovers Codex Sinaiticus at St. Catherine's Monastery
items.description: Codex Sinaiticus is one of the oldest known Greek manuscripts. Composed sometime between AD 325 and AD 360, it contains portions of the Septuagint and the Greek New Testament.

items.id: Tischendorf publishes various editions of the Greek New Testament
items.label: Tischendorf publishes various editions of the Greek New Testament
items.description: Tischendorf produced eight editions of the Greek New Testament over his productive career, and is also remembered for his discovery of Codex Sinaiticus.

items.id: Westcott & Hort publish Greek New Testament
items.label: Westcott & Hort publish Greek New Testament
items.description: This edition of the Greek New Testament, the product of 28 years of work, represents an early edition of the critical text tradition.

items.id: Discovery of the Dead Sea Scrolls
items.label: Discovery of the Dead Sea Scrolls
items.description: The Dead Sea Scrolls include a number of important copies of the Hebrew Old Testament.
items.sources: “The Dead Sea Scrolls - Discovery and Publication,” accessed December 13, 2013, http://www.deadseascrolls.org.il/learn-about-the-scrolls/discovery-and-publication.

items.id: Gutenberg prints copies of the Latin Vulgate, known as the 'Gutenberg Bible'
items.label: Gutenberg prints copies of the Latin Vulgate, known as the 'Gutenberg Bible'
Anglo-Saxon period
items.imagecredit: A reconstruction of the helmet found at Sutton Hoo, probably belonging to Raedwald of East Anglia, who died around 624. Based on a Roman parade-helmet design, it has decorations similar to those found in contemporary Swedish helmets found at Old Uppsala.

items.id: Crossway obtains permission to use RSV as base for ESV
items.label: Crossway obtains permission to use RSV as base for ESV
items.description: 'In 1998, [Wayne] Grudem and Lane Dennis, president of Crossway Books, obtained permission from the National Council of Churches, which owned the [RSV] copyright, to use the 1971 revision of the RSV as the starting point for their new version. The RSV itself had already been replaced by the New Revised Standard Version in 1990. In 1999 Crossway announced that the ESV would be forthcoming.'

items.label: The Living Bible
items.description: The Living Bible (TLB) is an English version of the Bible created by Kenneth N. Taylor. Unlike most English Bibles, The Living Bible is a paraphrase. Taylor used the American Standard Version of 1901 as his base text.

items.label: New Living Translation (NLT)
items.description: The New Living Translation (NLT) is a translation of the Bible into modern English. Originally starting out as an effort to revise The Living Bible, the project evolved into a new English translation from Hebrew and Greek texts. Some stylistic influences of The Living Bible remained in the first edition (1996), but these are less evident in the second edition (2004, 2007).

items.label: New Living Translation (NLT), second edition
items.description: The New Living Translation (NLT) is a translation of the Bible into modern English. Originally starting out as an effort to revise The Living Bible, the project evolved into a new English translation from Hebrew and Greek texts. Some stylistic influences of The Living Bible remained in the first edition (1996), but these are less evident in the second edition (2004, 2007).

items.label: NLT, second edition revision
items.description: The New Living Translation (NLT) is a translation of the Bible into modern English. Originally starting out as an effort to revise The Living Bible, the project evolved into a new English translation from Hebrew and Greek texts. Some stylistic influences of The Living Bible remained in the first edition (1996), but these are less evident in the second edition (2004, 2007).

items.id: James Barr publishes The Semantics of Biblical Language
items.label: James Barr publishes The Semantics of Biblical Language
items.description:
James Barr's The Semantics of Biblical Language massively influenced evangelical scholarship and modern Bible translation. Despite Barr's controversial claims and rejection of inerrancy, his contributions have been helpful to conservative scholars (including his student Moisés Silva). The current publisher's description summarizes the book's influence as follows:

Behind the academic and innocently descriptive title of this book is to be found one of the most explosive works of biblical scholarship to be published in the 20th century. Certainly many of those who read it when it first appeared were never the same again, and it signalled the end of what had hitherto been a flourishing literature on biblical theology.

"In recent years," Barr writes in the Preface, "I have come to believe that one of the greatest dangers to sound and adequate interpretation of the Bible comes from the prevailing use of procedure which, while claiming to rest upon a knowledge of the Israelite and Greek ways of thinking, constantly mishandles and distorts the linguistic evidence of the Hebrew and Greek languages as they are used in the Bible. The increasing sense of dependence upon the Bible in the modern church only makes this danger more serious. The fact that these procedures have never to my knowledge been collected, analysed, and criticized in detail was the chief stimulus to my undertaking of this task myself."

His conclusions brought much criticism initially, but forty years later they still stand. This book is essential reading for any student of the Bible.

items.id: Moisés Silva publishes Biblical Words and Their Meaning
items.label: Moisés Silva publishes Biblical Words and Their Meaning
items.description: Moisés Silva's Biblical Words and Their Meaning has positively impacted conservative biblical scholarship.

items.id: Crossway releases ESV Permanent Text edition
items.label: Crossway releases ESV Permanent Text edition
items.description: Publisher explanation: Beginning in the summer of 2016, the text of the ESV Bible will remain unchanged—in the same way that the King James Version (KJV) has remained unchanged ever since the final KJV text was established almost 250 years ago (in 1769). Thus, all present and future editions of the ESV reprinted and published by Crossway will contain the Permanent Text of the ESV Bible—throughout the life of the copyright, in perpetuity. This means that current readers of the ESV Bible—as well as their children and grandchildren—will be able to read, study, and memorize the ESV unchanged for generations to come. Click here to see a complete list of word changes in the ESV text.
items.sources: Crossway announcement page; Copy stored on Internet Archive

items.id: B&H announces forthcoming revision to HCSB
items.label: B&H announces forthcoming revision to HCSB
items.description: From press release: B&H Publishing Group announced today the completed revision of the Holman Christian Standard Bible (HCSB). Renamed the Christian Standard Bible® (CSB), the text will be available in a full line of Bibles for readers of all ages, with initial products releasing March 2017. Bibles in the HCSB will continue to be available in its award-winning product lines through 2017.

items.label: Minor revision to ESV
items.description: Wikipedia: The ESV underwent a minor revision in 2007, and the publisher did not identify the updated text as a revised edition. The update changed about 500 words by focusing on grammar, consistency and clarity. The most notable change was 'wounded for our transgressions' to 'pierced for our transgressions.'

items.label: Second minor revision to ESV
items.description: This revision represented a subsequent update to the 2007 edition.

items.id: Crossway reverses decision to release ESV Permanent Text
items.label: Crossway reverses decision to release ESV Permanent Text
items.description:
Crossway announces that they 'have become convinced' that the decision to release a permanent text was a mistake:

We have become convinced that this decision was a mistake. We apologize for this and for any concern this has caused for readers of the ESV, and we want to explain what we now believe to be the way forward. Our desire, above all, is to do what is right before the Lord.

Our goal at Crossway remains as strong as ever to serve future generations with a stable ESV text. But the means to that goal, we now see, is not to establish a permanent text but rather to allow for ongoing periodic updating of the text to reflect the realities of biblical scholarship such as textual discoveries or changes in English over time. These kinds of updates will be minimal and infrequent, but fidelity to Scripture requires that we remain open in principle to such changes, as the Crossway Board of Directors and the ESV Translation Oversight Committee see fit in years ahead.

See the source blog post for the full statement.

items.label: NET Bible, Second Edition
items.description:
From the Preface to the Second edition:

The most substantial editing work for this Second Edition centered on the essential task of creating an updated Strong’s Hebrew/Greek to English mapping of the entire translation. This allowed the discovery of discrepancies and inconsistencies as well as creating a collating base for comparing consistency across the entire Bible. We completed many items on our list of initiatives for the Second Edition:

  1. Both OT and NT have updated Strong’s tagged using phrase tagging as well as multiple number tagging.
  2. This detailed Strong’s tagging was used to detect and correct inconsistencies across the OT.
  3. Divine names in the OT have been made more consistent.
  4. Technical terms related to geography, feast names, and the tabernacle have been made more consistent.
  5. References to explicit sexual body parts or sexual acts have been made more euphemistic like it is in the Hebrew and Greek. Sometimes a more transparent translation isn’t always better, such as reading the Christmas story with young children.
  6. Awkward/unidiomatic renderings were revised, and
  7. Hebrew references in footnotes were corrected and standardized.
items.sources: NET Bible 'About' page [archived copy], NET Bible Preface [archived copy]

items.label: Christian Standard Bible (CSB)
items.description: Yahweh
gender-accurate
brothers and sisters
items.sources: A Review of the Christian Standard Bible.

items.label: Legacy Standard Bible
items.description: In a webcast message to Grace Community Church during the COVID-19 pandemic, John MacArthur announced a new Bible translation project, known as the Legacy Standard Bible. This translation will be a licensed update of the New American Standard Bible (NASB), with permission from the Lockman Foundation. The New Testament, Psalms, and Proverbs will be available at the March 2021 Shepherd’s Conference, with the completed edition to be released at a later date.

items.label: CSB releases minor update
items.description: http://themelios.thegospelcoalition.org/article/a-review-of-the-christian-standard-bible

items.label: Evangelical Heritage Version
items.description: The Evangelical Heritage Version (EHV) is a translation of the Bible into the English language. The translation project was called The Wartburg Project and the group of translators consisted of pastors, professors, and teachers from the Wisconsin Evangelical Lutheran Synod (WELS) and Evangelical Lutheran Synod (ELS).
